What you have stated about the bullet is not true.  The bullet would still make progress towards other galaxies, despite the universe expanding faster than the bullet can travel.  This is easily explained by the ant on the rubber rope paradox (ironically explained by vsause2), where the bullet is the ant, and the rope is the expanding universe.  Sure The space in front of the bullet is expanding faster than the bullet, but so is space behind the bullet. This expansion pushes the bullet along at the same rate as the space in front of it, thus the bullet still makes progress.  I await your retraction.

The bullet being forever alone is actually wrong. Space time expansion doesn't work like that. Consider the ant on a rubber band analogy. If an ant starts traveling from one end and the rubber band is expanding at a constant rate, the ant would still be moving along the rubber band. Every passing second, it would have increased the percentage distance covered along the rubber band even if the rubber band is expanding and eventually reach the other end, after a very very long time though as percentage increase in the distance covered by the ant would decrease every second.

einstein founded relativity not newton. newton said that objects attract by a force directly proportional to the mass of a object and the inverse of the square of the distance between them. However Einstein unified space and time into space-time and said that both space and time are not constant but can be curved by mass and that this curvature causes objects to accelerate towards other objects and depending on the velocity and mass of the accelerating object it will do one of three things:
1: "fall" to the surface of the larger object this happens when the velocity is below the escape velocity of the larger object.
2: the object goes into orbit this is usually elliptical (note: i am int sure at what velocity this happens at and would be interested if someone could fill me in)
3: the object slightly curves its direction. most commonly seen as the sun bending the light of stars behind it. this happens when the velocity is above thta of the required escape velocity of the mass. of course this all breaks down on the quantum level but I'll leave that for another day.

I'm not sure we should shoot out bullets randomly. Even though they might not reach another galaxy they might reach closer objects close enough to be captured into their gravitational pull. Unlike energy beams which always diverge and become harmless after a certain distance (there's a reason why they use beam weapons in sci fi movies), ballistic projectiles stay dangerous until they hit something. Hmm, noticed a slight linguistic inaccuracy:

Latin prefix 'dis-' means 'apart, asunder' from the Greek 'δις' meaning twice, in two separate parts. The prefix for 'against' in Latin is 'ante-' or 'anti-' from the Greek 'Αντα' or 'Αντι'.

I've had a strong interest in Field Artillery since the first time I saw a 105mm Battery "cut loose" at Fort Ord in central California in 1969.  I was talking with guys from the 25th "Tropic Lightning" division who were training with the 7th at Fort Ord.  Even at my young age I realized that if you could increase the Velocity of a 105mm enough that you could get enough Range to fire it completely around the World and "shoot yourself in the back of the head".  This knowledge would be innate to anyone who understood our Range Cards enough and had a great imagination.  Escape Velocity is just the next obvious step.  Some things take great minds, like Isaac Newton and other things are just common sense to people that work with obscure objects (like artillery) and have an active imagination.  Artillery Rounds or Space Shuttles are using the exact same ideas with different propellants.  Thanks Michael for another GREAT video!

I enjoy your videos, and think you do an amazing job with the way you explain things, but I would like to make an observation. Many of the ideas you are putting forth in this video are just theory , yet they are stated it as if they were fact.

If you want to provoke thought, you would explain this. Teach people how to think, not what to think. But this is sadly much like the public school system, which indoctrinates minds, rather than enlightening them by encouraging them to truly think for themselves.

I know these are fun videos and I my intention is not to bash on you, and be a "negative Nancy", but the thing is, people will inevitably just parrot these claims and not understand that there are differing ideas about how these things work, because they have not been told they are theories.

You may think this is an insignificant thing, but it is absolutely crucial as it relates to the future of our people. Children now-a-days are being taught what to think, while at the same time, made to believe that they are thinking critically. This has enslaved the minds of our boys and girls, and our men and women, who are more and more unlikely to come up with new ideas because they have been taught not to question the "facts" they have been handed . They have accepted the world as it was given to them, and know not how to challenge the accepted boundaries of science and reality.

I hope one day the institutions of education will learn how to inspire true thought, and not stifle it by asserting theory as fact, and putting up barriers where no barrier exists.

Sincerely,

I'm sorry, Vsauce, but I think you're wrong about one thing: Even if space expands faster than the speed of a bullet, the bullet will STILL reach the end. This is because the bullet itself also "rides the expansion", along with its own speed. Basically, space expands ahead AND behind the bullet. The proportion of space that is ahead of the bullet will keep shrinking as the bulliet travels, whereas the proportion of space behind the bullet will keep increasing. That means that the expansion of space will increasingly take place behind the bullet instead of ahead of it. Yes, the end of space is moving away from the bullet initially, despite the bullet's speed, but the speed at which the end of space keeps moving away decreases over time until, at some point, the bullet will start to catch up again and finally reach the end of space :-)

Dani - allow replies. I'll answer for anyone else who might be wondering the same thing. The question was :

"How come stars closer to the center of the Milky Way orbit faster than the sun does".

The stars closer to the center of the Milky Way orbit faster than the sun for the same reason that Mercury orbits the sun faster than Jupiter. The closer you are to your orbiting parent, the faster you must go in order to maintain that orbit. It's basic orbital mechanics. The force of gravity gets weaker the farther you are from the source of gravity.

Perhaps you should understand how orbits work :

Imagine you shoot a bullet out of a gun here on Earth from 1 meter above the ground - parallel to the ground. This bullet will accelerate due to gravity at 9.8 m/s² (ignoring drag) downward regardless of it's lateral velocity. In a perfectly flat world, the bullet fired from the gun would reach the ground at the exact same time as a bullet that was simply dropped from the same height at the same time.

In reality, the bullet fired from the gun took a TINY bit longer to reach the surface? Why? It's because the Earth is not flat. It is a sphere, so the bullet that was fired actually traveled some distance across the surface of the Earth, and the Earth's curvature would very slightly come into play. Now, a bullet fired from a regular gun won't go far enough in the time it takes it to fall to make a noticeable difference. Suppose you had a super gun that could fire the bullet at any speed you like.

If you fired that bullet fast enough, you could make it so that in the time it takes the bullet to fall the 1 meter, it traveled so far across the surface of the Earth that the Earth actually curved away from the bullet by that same meter. In all the time that bullet was falling, it never actually got any closer to the surface of the Earth. Now, in reality - this could never work from 1 meter above the surface because the bullet would surely run into something and the air would slow it way down. But, in space - you don't have to worry about any of those things. So, if you get a satellite going fast enough laterally, it will be falling "around" the Earth - and never getting any closer.

Remember though, that the farther you are away, the weaker the gravitational force - which means the acceleration decreases. So, the orbiting body doesn't fall DOWN as fast - therefore it doesn't need to be traveling across the surface as fast - because it takes the object longer to fall. So, an object farther away has a slower orbital speed.

Just because the universe expands at 200 km/s doesn't mean a bullet could never reach another star or galaxy.  That would imply, as we've long since known is false, that the earth is the center of the universe.  Instead, we're travelling outward from the same origin point at the same speed, just at a different angle.  It's like two boats fighting to travel up river, starting at the same point but heading for docks on opposite shores.  With a little trigonometry, it's easy to shoot the second boat from the first, so long as the differential component velocity between the the two boats and acting in the direction of the bullet doesn't exceed the speed of the bullet.  Considering the velocities at which the two celestial bodies travel, this means they have to be travelling almost parallel to each other, but not absolutely.

Paused at 2:12 to point out, if you shot water at the sun... well, it wouldn't freeze.  Assuming you were in space when you shot your water gun and therefore the water is in the (near perfect) vacuum of space, it would actually boil due to the lack of pressure.
Anyway, while I'm here and already typing (I do love the sound of my own typing) I would predict that you in fact COULD NOT 'put out' the sun by throwing water at it.  Because of its high atomic weight & position along the chain of nuclear fusion, I am uncertain as to what the effect of the oxygen from the water would do... but the hydrogen (by numbers the more significant constituent of the water) would only add fuel to the fusion reaction.
Thinking about it further, I suppose the only point at which the sun would go out due to added water would be when there was so much water that the additional mass and hydrogen fuel caused it to do all the fun things that really big stars do :D

@Vsauce I believe you made a factual error while explaining Fusion reaction..... Fusion is not when two atomic hydrogen makes a bond to form H2 gas (this is actually a chemical reaction, the kind that happens in earth all the time) rather it is when two hydrogen nuclei reacts to each other to form a Helium nuclei.... the process also generates 2 neutrinos and 6 photons.....

Nuclear reactions (Fusion or fission) and chemical reactions are fundamentally different, what you explained is a chemical reaction, not Fusion..... Chemical reactions occur between the valance electrons of two or more elements, while in a nuclear reaction, it the the nuclei of the atoms that participate.... and this often changes the proton number and thereby giving rise to a new element....

Oops. It's not actually true that a bullet travelling at a few km/s would have no chance of ever reaching a galaxy receding at 200 km/s. That's because the galaxy is not moving away at 200 km/s -- rather, the space between is expanding, creating an apparent relative motion of 200 km/s. Although the bullet's speed is much smaller than that apparent relative motion, once the bullet starts out the space is then expanding both before AND behind the bullet, so the proportion of the distance covered by the bullet is never lost. The bullet can make steady progress proportionally across that expanding distance. It may take a very VERY long time, but it is possible that it actually arrives. Eventually.

Well, you couldn't put out the Sun using liquid water because, among several other things, it would boil in the vacuum of space, then it would turn into ice and then it would boil again until there was no ice left, for as long and the Sun shone upon it.
EXPAND THIS FOR A MORE DETAILED EXPLANATION.

That would happen due to the sudden absence of pressure acting upon the liquid water, which would act faster than the space cooling process (heat sink caused by the hard vacuum of space), this means that the gaseous state (vapor) would come before the solid state (ice).
In case radiation heat were high enough, that ice would sublimate (i.e. turn directly into gas, skipping the liquid state) until there was no ice left. 

Pressure and temperature are the ones that keep water in a liquid state, in the vacuum of space there is no pressure and the radiation heat in deep space (far from any star/radiation source) is pretty low, so any liquid water released there would first turn into vapor (because the lack of pressure would apply instantly.), and then that vapor would "desublimate" (i.e. a gas turns directly into a solid, skipping the liquid state due to very low/lack of temperature and pressure.) forming ice crystals as it radiated its remaining heat away.
And it would remain so until it got close enough to a radiation source like the Sun, then its radiation heat balance would turn positive (that ice would get more radiation than it lost) so it would heat up again, but in the absence of pressure (hard vacuum of space) the ice would "sublimate" (i.e. skip the liquid state and turn directly into a gas). If that chunk of ice were large enough, we would call it a comet and we would say it had a tail (the tail being the ice sublimated by the Sun's radiation heat).

Think of it as a nerd at school who is always being bullied by bullies who have a vacuum instead of a brain, so they are cold as shit. When she gets bullied, she only has two options: either to act tough or to fart on their faces. Those are the only two effective ways she has to withstand the bullying. She has also tried a third way which consists in pissing on those bullies, but she always gets beaten when she tries it.
One day, two girls decide to join forces and protect the nerd from the cold vacuum head bullies. One of those girls can perform "bear hugs" so strong that take the breath away from her rivals, and the other girl can slap them so fast that their faces turn hot. By combining their powers in the right way, the nerd is able to piss on the bullies, who then decide to leave her be. But some other times, her protectors either fall short or overdo it, they hit/hug too softly or too harshly (or a combination of both) and then the bullies don't stop. However, all this can only happen when her protectors are there, since the bullies revert to their previous behavior when they leave the nerd all by herself.
Keep in mind that this only works with this specific nerd, since the bullies act differently with other nerds, sometimes it takes much more effort to make them stop, sometimes it takes much less, it always depends on the nerd.

In this case, just think of the nerd as water and imagine that those two protectors are pressure and temperature: you can't have liquid water without the right amount of temperature and pressure, otherwise liquid water will either evaporate and/or solidify.

Remember, it's not the same to expose a chunk of ice to the vacuum of space as doing so using liquid water. A chunk of ice will remain mostly solid in space as long as radiation heat from stars/other sources remains low, it can partially sublimate if it isn't cold enough but its vapor will eventually desublimate if that region of space is cold enough (there's low radiation heat).
But liquid water, on the other hand, will always instantly boil first and, depending on the level of radiation heat, will either remain a gas or desublimate, it can't remain liquid because there's never enough pressure in a hard vacuum to force it into that state.

Recoil is a potential problem in orbit/low gravity.  Recoil impulse would cause an astronaut to rotate unless he was anchored or could compensate with thrusters.  The ergonomic challenges of aiming and firing a gun in a space suit (bulk, resistance, dexterity, tactile feedback) might be prohibitive of basic marksmanship.  Firing a weapon inside of a spacecraft could depressurize the spacecraft. 

A cannon on a space craft would act as another thruster, altering its velocity.  Other thrusters could be fired to compensate.  A rotating turret, if it were massive enough, could also change the velocity (speed, direction) of the spacecraft due to conservation of angular momentum.  Additionally, a turret with a wide range of rotation and elevation could place recoil impulse at a vector that thrusters could not compensate for, possibly resulting in gimbal lock.  

The US Military developed recoil-less weapons to use in space.  It was a smooth-bore pistol firing a self-contained, spin-stabilized compressed gas cartridge.  It worked, but it required a certain distance to develop lethal velocity - thus making it useless at close range (inside a spacecraft).  Its hard to find info on, I've only ever found photos of it in an older book.

Not to be outdone, the Russians developed an underwater assault rifle, the APS.  Its a smooth-bore weapon built on a modified Kalashnikov receiver firing long steel darts for stability/range in liquid.  This one worked well, but could only be fired a few times in air in an emergency or you would damage the barrel.

Russians also placed a 23mm cannon on their Almaz spy space station.  Just to see what would happen, they test fired the weapon remotely.

The most practical/effective man-portable weapon to be used in space would likely be a rocket propelled weapon such as the USM136/AT4 or Carl-Gustav recoilless rifle.  Maybe.

Alright, I guess I will take a crack at explaining it. First off I am not going to use numbers or equations, because that just seems to confuse people even further. For starters infinity is a concept, not a number. So people who keep saying that there is only one infinity are wrong. Since infinity is a concept that means it is only limited to whatever numbers you include into infinity. Now going with what the guy in this video was saying if you counted on a number line from one to forever you would never reach infinity. Instead of putting this to practice most of us just think, "Ok it goes on forever." well this is "countable". Now let us throw in numbers we did not consider like decimals because we did not consider the full scope of what we were looking at before this, this is a new even bigger infinity. Now lets move to the final infinity with decimals, we can start to count one number say starting with 0 then we go to the next decimal. Except no matter how far we move the decimal place over we will NEVER reach the number that will finally let us take the first number in our list. So looking at this concept you reached infinity without even counting to one. :P

With some rough calculations and quick research - the delta-V caused from firing a .50 caliber semi-auto rifle would be about .55 m/s.  That's still not much considering the muzzle velocity to be about 930 m/s. That's only a loss of 0.05% for the projectile.  That's pretty much nothing.  Though, if you had a 10-round mag, you could give yourself a Delta-V of about 5.5 m/s.  Not much, but its something.

This is true, but not by much.  I've calculated this before, and I think I got a delta-V of about .03 m/s for an average human firing a 9mm.  Conservation of momentum means that the velocity of the bullet would also only decrease by .03 m/s. When they say - launching as fast as the Earth curves away - they are NOT talking about the rotation of the Earth; they are talking about the CURVATURE of the Earth.  As far as calculating the orbital velocities necessary to achieve orbit, the Earth can be considered motionless.  The rotation of the Earth has absolutely zilch to do with the orbital velocity necessary to orbit.

The orbital velocity needed to orbit the Earth is exactly the same (for the same altitude) regardless of the direction of your orbit.  This velocity is relative to the center of the Earth.  Most satellites orbit prograde (same direction of rotation) because it requires less delta V to achieve orbit since you gain the velocity from the rotation of the Earth.  A retrograde orbit requires more delta V, but the final orbital velocity relative to the Earth's center is exactly the same either way.

Correct, though gravity is not really zero at the center.  There is indeed gravity at the center, it just acts on you in all directions (away from the center - toward the surrounding mass), and the NET force is zero.  If you dug the hole through the rotational axis, the coriolis effect would not occur.  You'd still have drag to deal with, though.

That's completely incorrect. First, the satellite is *falling* the entire time, not accelerating (which is an increase in speed). Second, the orbital speed of an object varies with its distance from the body it's orbiting. Speed increases as the distance decreases, and decreases as distance increases. A perfectly circular orbit results in a constant speed, whereas a highly elliptical orbit results in a widely varying speed. Comets are good examples of the latter.

Any atoms in it's path should be expanding away from the bullet, so impacts should be extremely rare.

That said, if a bullet with a mass of 1 gram and a velocity of 1000 meters per second hits a stationary object with a mass of 1 gram they would both end up with a velocity of 500 meters per second if there were a perfect transfer of momentum. The same would be true for impacting individual atoms with a combined mass of 1 gram. If it hit enough atoms it would eventually stop.

Well, there is a chance that we are indeed alone. This chance is so low that it is hardly worth considering, but it's there, and as long as we haven't been able to discover alien life, we have to recognize it as a possibility. Just as we don't know if the universe is actually infinite in space, so we have to recognize the possibility of it being finite. What's truly amazing is that if space IS infinite, there MUST be alien life, but if it isn't, it doesn't have to be there.

I once pondered if there's a limit to how infinite the universe can be: the universe we live in is said to be infinite in space, but finite in time, meaning it had a beginning and will have an end. Concluding that, fictional worlds that are finite in space, such as Narnia and Middle-Earth, might never have had a beginning, and won't have an end.

If you take a look at any water phase diagram, you will find that at the temperatures that water can exist in liquid form, it can ONLY exist as a gas at the pressures it would be exposed to in space.  It would INDEED boil.  It might eventually make its way into ice form, but it would certainly NOT be due to the water freezing.  The water would immediately boil at near zero pressures.  Again - it can't freeze.

It will boil LONG before it's heat is radiated away enough for it to freeze due to the lack of pressure.  When I say "LONG before", I mean IMMEDIATELY.  Liquid water cannot exist in zero pressure.

Space is not a vacuum because something is containing it.  It is just the nature of space.  There is nothing there......except space.  An to be technical, space is not a perfect vacuum.  There are still random molecules (mostly hydrogen) roaming around.  As for the expansion.  Your confusion is normal.  It is kind of a tough concept to grasp, but space itself is expanding.  It's not expanding INTO anything.

Water will boil in space.  You said it yourself.  In zero pressure (space), at the temperatures at which liquid water can exist, it can only exist as a gas in space.  Using this simple logic, liquid water will boil in space.  It will not freeze.  At least not before it boils.
The reason for your flawed thinking is having the incorrect assumption that the sun is 'on fire' or 'burning'.  It isn't.  Did you even watch the video?

Time is relative..  Which means, relative to YOU.  Wherever you are, whatever ever you are doing, or wherever you are going, time always moves at the same rate to YOU.  When you are in motion, it stays the same to you, but slows down in everything else's perspective(extremely tiny amounts).  The faster YOU go, the slower you are going to everyone else.  As you approach the speed of light you would stop to everyone else, but the universe would seem to be normal to you.  Relativity in a nutshell.

Currently, the same way we tell time now.  With a clock or chronometer.  I don't go outside and look for the position of the sun or moon to tell time.  Do you do that?  I'd love lessons on doing so.  That's a skill they don't teach in schools anymore(if ever).

If you controlled your decent, you would end up weightless, which is inaccurate.  Weightless is lack of gravity.  What you would experience in the core of the earth, if it were hollow like the video example, would be floating, with gravity pulling you from all directions.  Since the crust has mass, it is attracting your mass.  You are in the middle(absolute center) of all that mass, so you get an equal pull from all sides.  You would, in essence, be floating, but not weightless.

The sun isn't made of FIRE..  It's plasma, which by the time any water you sent toward it got there, it would be heated and turned to plasma as well.  Increasing the suns total mass.  Simple 6th grade science.

Guns do work in space.  Those little bullets are sealed.  There's no AIR needed for them to fire.  They have an oxidizer built in.  They fire under water where there is no oxygen readily available, why wouldn't they fire in space?

The Universe is Expanding.  Everything expands.  Like the surface on a balloon.  Take an un-inflated balloon, make 5 dots, rather close to each other, on the balloon.  Then blow it up.  Watch how the dots move apart.  It's SPACE that is expanding.  It's hard to explain.  And with the gun point, most understood the fact that the gun would be fired in the vacuum of space.  You take out your most powerful rifle and that bullet wont escape earths gravity.

Andromeda is an exception since it is BLUE shifted.  The only known galaxy that is coming at us.  If you pointed it at any other galaxy out there, the bullet would NEVER catch up.  Not only because of the sheer velocity of the galaxy, but because of Expansion.  All other galaxies are expanding faster than any bullet we have at our disposal can fire, so the bullet would seem to be moving backwards.  Forever getting further away, though from the shooters perspective moving toward the object.

Here's my explanation: If you shot the bullet near a planet, it would travel endlessly in orbit due to the law of inertia (or at least until it hit other space junk). If you shot it in open space it would travel until the gravity of a larger planet, asteroid, or other space junk pulled it into orbit. The "smoke trail" would look like an expanding sphere. The person that shot the gun would travel backwards at about 2cm per second due to recoil.

Acceleration is a vector quantity. It has a direction.  If something is slowing down, then the acceleration vector MUST be pointing in the opposite direction of the velocity vector.  An object thrown in the air is being accelerated toward the center of Earth for the entire flight (fall).  An object in orbit is accelerating toward the center of the Earth the entire time it is orbiting, and the acceleration is that due to gravity.  The object is in free fall, and that is synonymous with falling.

Then you do not understand what acceleration is.  You need to pick up a physics book and learn about the things that you pretend to know about.  Acceleration is a change in velocity.  If you go from 10 m/s to 20 m/s in one second, then your acceleration is 10 m/s² in the direction of motion.  If you go from 20 m/s to 10 m/s in one second, then your acceleration is 10 m/s² in the OPPOSITE direction of motion.  Cont....

Free fall is when a body is moving towards the Earth unconstrained by wings, parachute or engine. In orbit, a body is not moving towards the Earth: Its distance from the centre of the Earth remains constant, ergo it is not falling. Umm no.  That is not how Newton's 3rd law works.  Yes, there is an equal and opposite force acting on you, but that certainly does not mean that you will be accelerated at the same rate as the bullet.  If that were true, then you wouldn't have to be in space to see this.  People on Earth would not be able to fire guns either.  F=ma....remember this?  This means that a=F/m.  The person shooting a gun has WAY more mass than the bullet, so the person's acceleration is WAY less than the bullet.

Astronauts were free falling all the way to the moon as well.  Again, falling is accelerating due to gravity.  Your velocity need not be TOWARD the source of gravity in order to be falling toward it.  The astronauts were accelerating toward the Earth all the way to the moon; until the moon's gravitational influence was the predominant one, and even then, they are most definitely still free falling - all the way until they start the engines to land (or course correct).  Basic physics, man.

You are certainly falling when in orbit.  Free fall is simply when gravity is the only force acting on a body, and objects in orbit certainly fit that criteria.  While they may be moving forward, they are still very much accelerating consistent with gravity.  Their speed may not change, but remember, acceleration is a change in VELOCITY, and velocity is a vector quantity with a speed AND a direction, and objects in orbit are constantly changing direction, therefore accelerating due to falling.

This is not true -- you are not constantly falling when in orbit. If you run and jump, there is a point where you are not going up and you are not going down, only moving forward. The formula for the combustion of sulfur-free (smokeless) gunpowder is:
6KNO3 + C7H8O → 3K2CO3 + 4CO2 + 2H2O + 3N2
As you can see, the potassium nitrate and C7H80 (the two compounds that make up smokeless powder) contain all of the molecules necessary for a balanced decomposition reaction without any added oxygen. As such, you could detonate gunpowder in a vacuum such as that of space without a problem.

At 2:00 you said the water would be frozen. This is not true at all. It would be vapor from having boiled away to nothing. When you expose water to a vacuum it boils due to a loss of pressure. This is why you can boil water at lower temps at high altitude. 
By changing the amount of pressure around the water you change the temperature at which it boils. So out in space where there's no pressure it instantly boils into vapor without needing to be heated at all.

The sun isn't 'burning' ANYTHING.  The sun is basically a giant nuclear reactor.  The energy, heat, and light all come from a process called nuclear fusion.  Inside the sun, there are hydrogen atoms that are being compressed so tightly (due to gravity) that they combine to form helium atoms.  There are always particles left over from this fusion, and those particles are converted into pure energy.  It is consistent with Einstein's equation e=mc².  A tiny amount of mass = a HUGE amount of energy.

You are saying that the bullet would continue to accelerate.  Why?  There are no forces acting on the bullet to cause acceleration.  Remember Newton's law of inertia?  "Every object in uniform motion will remain in uniform motion unless a net force acts on that object"

The propellant in the casing exerted a force on the bullet that resulted in a velocity of 1 km/s.  After that, it will continue in uniform motion (maintain 1 km/s) because there will be no other forces acting on it.

1600 km/hr is 444 m/s.  Assuming the acceleration is constant inside a barrel 1/10 of a meter long, the acceleration is 985,680 m/s².  I will use 8 grams as the mass of the bullet.  The force on the bullet :

F=ma=(.008)(985,680)= 7,885 Newtons.  

Acceleration of a 70 kg human :

a=F/m=7,885/70=113 m/s² (notice it is the same force that acts on the bullet)

The force is only applied for .0005 sec (average vel (222) / distance (.1))

Change in human velocity=v=at=(113)(.0005)=.05m/s.

in the diagram, water is a vapor at all temperatures when the pressure is zero.  Left that part out.  Still wanna defend your position that water boils in space because it gets so hot?

And maybe you should go look at your water phase diagram one more time.  You DO realize that there are two sides to this diagram, right?  You see along the bottom where it says 'temperature'?  Now look along the left.  What's that say?  Oh, yeah. It says PRESSURE.  And did you notice that water is a vapor at ALL temperatures? If you want to source a scientific model as support for your argument, you might want to make sure you know how to read it before using it. Because it supports MY position.

In fact, when you are applying heat to water, it doesn't boil because it is hot (not directly) - the REASON it boils is because raising the temp of water brings the vapor pressure of the water to the air pressure of the surrounding air.  So the bottom line is, pressure is what matters when talking about the boiling point of water.  So you can either heat the water up to raise the pressure of the vapor......OR.....lower the pressure of the surrounding air.  You pick...either way, you're wrong.

Then explain to me why you think water will boil at room temperature if you expose it to a vacuum.  Are you aware that you can put a cup of water in a chamber, suck all the air out, and it will boil?  That has nothing to do with heat, but pressure.  Pressure is required to hold the molecules together in a liquid state, and in a vacuum, that pressure doesn't exist, so water boils.  You can easily verify this by watching any of the dozen to hundred videos of people boiling water by removing air.

Here's the math
An average 9mm bullet goes 425 m/s.  Length of the barrel = .102 meters.  Mass of 9mm bullet=8g. Time taken for the bullet to leave the barrel (time force was applied) 
t=d/½v = .102/212.5 = .00048 seconds.  Acceleration of the bullet > a=v/t=425/.00048 = 885,416.67m/s².  So the force on the bullet is F=ma=(.008)(885,416.67) = 7,083.3 Newtons.  So MY acceleration is a=F/m=7,083.3/70= 101.2 m/s².  Then change in velocity = at = (101.2)(.00048) = .04 m/s. So .04m/s is all it did.

Part 2 of 2

The time it would take for the bullet to come back down is 2v/g where v is the initial velocity (bullet speed) and g is the acceleration of gravity (9.8 m/s²).  One important note is that the acceleration due to gravity decreases as you move farther from Earth, so this equation is not exactly accurate since even for an M16 bullet (975 m/s), the acceleration at the peak has dropped to 9.6 m/s².  However, it will get you in the ballpark.  So about 3 minutes and 18 seconds for an M16.

Part 1 of 2

Gravtity would 'kick in' immediately.  The chances of it landing where you fired are not good.  Wind currents and other things would surely keep that from happening.  If there were no air, and you shot exactly straight up, it would land exactly where you shot from.  It would also land with the same velocity as the initial velocity when fired.

In other words, if you took a ship 385,000 km above the surface of the Earth (same height of average moon orbit), but not near the moon (opposite side or just far enough away to not be influenced by lunar gravity), then shot the gun in the proper direction (90 degrees to your right or left while looking directly at Earth), the bullet would probably be in a stable orbit.  You'd just have to get to a point where an initial velocity of 1,114 m/s would work, and that would be 385,000 km away.

It could maintain a stable orbit if that were the orbital velocity at the same distance as the moon orbits the Earth.  However, you'd need to have a delta-V well over 1,114 m/s in order to reach that orbital height to begin with, so you could never get there.  So, I guess 'no' is the answer!

I meant, they are 300-400 km from the SURFACE of the Earth.  Which puts them 300-400 farther from the center than people at the surface.  Since people at the surface are already 6,375 km away, the astronauts are only 6,675-6775 km away.  Which is 4.7%-6.3% farther, so they really are not all that much farther away than we are.  Sorry for misspeaking.

They are 300-400 km from the CENTER of the Earth.  At the surface of the Earth (where we are), we are about 6,375 km from the center.  So the astronauts are 6.3 % farther than people at the surface.  Now, the source of gravity is not from the center of the Earth, but for the purposes of calculating the force of gravity of a celestial (spherical) body, you can assume the entire mass of the celestial body is located at a point at the center of mass.  In this case, they are not much farther.

Also, the meter has not always been defined with respect to the speed of light.  This definition is pretty modern.  Also worth noting is the fact that 1)the definition of the meter is logically circular; meaning that the speed of light is based on the meter, and the meter is based on the speed of light. This kind of definition will work with ANY unit of measure. and 2) No human being has any reasonable grasp on how much time 1/299,792,458 seconds is nor the speed of light. Its just mathematical.

The meter is defined that way because it is the SI unit of measure, and it is the standard in physics, whose most prominent constant is the speed of light.  It is not shocking that the meter is defined that way.  This is not necessary for the yard. The number of people who adopt a set of units is not a testament to the invalidity of the others. It is mere preference.  As I said, my preference IS the meter.  In no way does it make the others wrong or invalid. What a waste of time this has been.

"That bullet would be Forever Alone..."
Oh, how I wish I could post ascii art here...

None of those units of measure are useless.  Many farmers still use these today because the units are based in the real world. Time never changes for you personally.  You are always in your reference frame.  Time dilation occurs due to relatvie velocities.  In other words, if you were moveing very fast relative to a friend, it would be the friend who observes your time moving more slowly.  You would not notice a thing.  The time would pass completely normal to you.  However, you would observe the time of your friend passing more slowly.  The same goes for mass.  You don't notice it, but your relative mass increases.

Before a nova can happen, it would be a white dwarf first.  The chances of the sun, after becoming a white dwarf (which WILL happen) exploding into a nova a very slim.  Novae occur typically in binary systems where the white dwarf will pull material off of the nearby star thus starting a runaway occurrence of nuclear fusion which will cause the nova.  The sun is not in a binary system, so it will just remain a white dwarf.  Either way, the point is the sun will NOT become a black hole.

Right.  I'm not the least bit confused.  I know what acceleration is.  If it is accelerating, there MUST be a force acting on it regardless if the acceleration is a change in direction or a change in speed.  If the bullet is orbiting, then this force would be gravity.  In other words, you can't have it both ways.  Either it is accelerating AND there is a net force or it is NOT accelerating and there is zero net force. Well, yes the effect I stated above may not cool it quick enough, there is one effect you are overlooking. As anything decompresses or expands, it actually gets colder. A simple way to prove this is to spray deodorant on your hand. It will feel very cold. That's because it expanded from its pressurised state. The water in space would act in the same way. it wouldn't freeze instantly, instead it would decompress a bit and then form lots of ice crystals like snowflakes.

By no more forces, I meant no more forces to speed up the bullet. Acceleration is actually a change in velocity, not just speed, and velocity is also which direction the object is travelling. The bullet is orbiting, so it is always changing direction. This in turn means the velocity is always changing, and therefore it is technically accelerating without speeding up. Sorry if it confused you a bit, it can be a hard concept to grasp.

The circumference of Earth is 40,075 km.  That divided by 24 hours is 1,670 km/hr (1,038 mph).  Just 100 km into the hole, THAT part of the Earth is going 1,617 km/hr (1,004 mph).  It is over 12,000 km all the way through the Earth, and just 100 km in, you are already going 34 mph FASTER than the hole.  You'll surely hit the side.

Yes, when you jump in the hole, you are rotating at the same speed as the Earth is, but only at the surface.  The farther down the hole you go, the slower that part of the Earth is rotating, however, YOU are still rotating as fast as the Earth was at the surface, so the farther down the hole you go, the faster you are going relative to the Earth.  Eventually you WILL hit the side.  This has already been proven to be true experimentally.

Actually, heat can be transferred not only as particle conduction (which requires a different specific heat capacity particle to be present nearby), but as a particle itself. Thermal infra-red radiation is given off by particles. It takes heat energy that the particle has, and turns it into a photon. This photon doesn't have to hit anything, but it will still take heat from the particle, in this case the water. Basically, the water radiates the heat out into space.

If a bullet is fired at 400 m/s, and the barrell of the gun is 6 inches long, then the force was being exerted for about .0004 seconds.  So, the acceleration of the bullet = dv/dt = 400/.0004 = 1,000,000 m/s².  The force = ma = .014*1,000,000 = 14,000 Newtons.  The acceleration of a 70kg mass = F/m = 14,000 / 70 = 200m/s².  Force was again applied for .0004 seconds so v=at = 200 * .0004 = .08 m/s.  Your way is obviously easier.  I just wanted to show that you get the same thing this way.

According to Newton, the velocity of an object will remain constant as long as there are no unbalanced forces acting on it.  This is not the case because gravity from the Earth, sun, moon, etc. will be exerting a force on whatever object you send to space for quite some time.  In fact, when we went to the moon, the astronauts are free-falling all the way there.  They are not coasting at a constant speed, but are slowing down (due to Earth) most of the way until the moon pulls them in.

Let's say you're still in space and you shoot a 14 g bullet at a speed of 400 m/s.  You have a mass of 70 kg (that's 155 pounds on Earth.)  Momentum is conserved, so mv = mv, so (0.014)(400) = (70)v, where the v is your velocity.  v comes out to be .08 m/s, which is about 4.29 miles per day (about the top speed of a sloth).  I'd say a gun would not make a very good jet pack (unless you're a sloth).  (You'd have to fire about 11 bullets to change your speed by 2 mph.)

Let's say you add hydrogen to a star, the adding of hydrogen increases it's mass and gravitational field. The increase in the gravitational field increases the rate hydrogen nuclei can fuse into helium. It turns out the increase in the rate hydrogen can then fuse outweighs the extra hydrogen in  the star.

So the star has more hydrogen, but "burns" more hydrogen per year and can then "burn" this larger amount of hydrogen faster than a smaller star burns a lesser amount.

The Earth is not falling relative to you. You are falling relative to the Earth.  In orbit, you have a sufficient velocity at a right angle to the pull of gravity such that as you fall, you never get any closer to the Earth because the Earth curves away from you as you fall (because you are going so fast).  When you jump, you don't have that speed, and you simply fall straight back down. Now, the Earth IS also falling, but it is falling (and everything on it including you) relative to the sun.

Suppose the the original bullet (A) has a speed of z m/s.
Bullet A can fire a bullet of equal mass at the same rate of z m/s.

In free space, bullet A would be accelerated in the opposite direction of travel (decelerated) by the firing of the new bullet (B), and bullet B would be accelerated toward the direction of travel.  

Bullet A would be traveling slower than z m/s, and bullet B would be going faster than z m/s, but NOT 2z.  Relative to bullet A, bullet B would be travling z m/s. Confused?

A gun would work perfectly fine in space.  Yes, oxygen would be required for the explosion, but all the oxygen needed for the explosion is already inside the bullet.  Even on Earth, bullets do not use the oxygen in the air to explose, but the oxygen already packed in with the gunpowder. In fact, because of the vaccuum in space, the explosion would be slightly more efficient in space. This all assumes of course that the bullet was packed in an atmosphere. If packed in a vaccuum, it will not fire.

He says "their angular velocity is so fast...". Nope, the angular velocity is pretty low. Its sqrt(g/r), where g is the acceleration due to gravity at the radius of the orbit they are in and this value is less than 10m/s^2. r, of course, is huge. So angular velocity is really low. The VELOCITY, on the other hand, is sqrt{gr}, which is HIGH!

cuz, it was a random comment and I wasn't trying to get a paper published.  I was just trying to suggest something to think about.  When you answered no, you completely disregarded the whole question.  I had no idea what your objection was. when it was an issue of scale, I decided to calculate the scale.  I still like the idea, with a long enough barrel and a bullet with enough surface area, you could fire projectiles with just air pretty damn fast.
Why did you even ask if you could work out the calculations on your own?

The surface area of the back of a bullet is about a cm in diameter.  that's ~3.14 cm^2 that air is pushing on.  a square meter is pushed on by about 10 tons by 1atm of air.  there are 10,000 square cm in a square meter, so 10tons/10,000cm^2=.0001 tons=.2 lbs per square cm.  so its roughly 3.14 cm^2*.2 lbs=.63 lbs.  So, yea, not even close to enough to hurt the bullet.  Neat.

In space these factors are much less if not so tiny they might as well be zero. To a bullet in space wouldn't slow down it would speed up. The same way that solar sails work in space but they do not work here on earth.

You misunderstand the conservation of energy. This law has a prerequisite that you must be unaware of;that is : that the sum of all energies remains the same 'IN A CLOSED SYSTEM'. Water boiling in space has an undefined boundary, therefore it is not a closed system, ergo, it breaks no laws. The frozen water currently in space has either always been frozen, or the result of desublimation. Never is the presence of frozen water the result of liquid water freezing before it boils and desublimates.

This is my last comment. Yes, the water will boil, but only briefly, and only a fraction of the water will become gas. Energy is conserved. Changing liquid water to gas needs energy, no matter under which condition. If in space all the water suddenly change into gas under vaccum (according to you), where the energy needed for this transformation comes from? The energy needs to be conserved at any moment. I can say nothing more. What you claimed breaks one of the basic laws of thermodynamics.

You cannot keep comparing the fundamentals of phase changes in matter under pressure with matter in a vaccuum.  They are fundamentally different.  You say that pressure is not the point.  If that is what you think, then your argument is dead in the water before you say another word.  And if you took that water which holds your defeated argument into space, it would surely boil.  I'm done repeating myself.

I already address the pressure problem. But this is not the point. When some of the water change from liquid to gas, no matter under pressure or under vaccum, will need energy. The energy conservation law requires that this energy needs to come from somewhere. In space, this energy can only come from lowering the temperature of the remaining water. The heat of evaporation of water is so high, that only a fraction of water can become gas in space. Fridge works in the same principle.

There is no need to insult me.  First, you have no idea who I am, and for that reason, your insults might as well be directed at the wall behind you, and second, the fact that you resort to such childish tactics takes every bit of validity out of the rest of your argument.  
It requires energy to boil water UNDER PRESSURE because it requires heat.  This is not required in a vaccuum.  Water will boil at any temperature.  It merely needs to EXIST in liquid form in a vaccuum to boil.  Not energy.

You really did not study hard in your physics class. Energy is conserved in this process. What you mean, I think is that, water will explode in space. That is right. But in this process, only a fraction of the water will become gas. The majority of the water will cool down. Where is the energy come from to make all the water change into gas? Remember, we are talking about something in space, no energy supply. Liquid water to gas require a huge amount of energy.

Water does not freeze in space directly.  I never claimed that ice cannot exist in space, I said that water does not freeze in space.  And it doesn't freeze.  The GAS freezes.  The water would immediately boil away, and then desblime, and this is where you get your ice.  As far as comets go, they are not made up of pure water ice, so it is not a good example of pure water (your scenario) frozen in space.  Again, water does not freeze in space.  It boils....THEN freezes, and boils immediately.

Boiling and evaporation, while producing the same outcome (liqiod to gas), are two fundametally different processes.  Boiling is not 'fast' evaporation.  Evaporation only occurs at the surface of a liquid, while boiling occurs throughout.  In space there is no pressure, so the entire mass of the liquid will boil simultaneously, while evaporation only occurs on the surface, and at a much slower rate than the boiling.  Ice can happen, but it is the BOILED gas that desublimes to form ice.

Boiling is fast evaporation. To keep boiling, you need to supply energy. Without continuous supply of energy, the boiling will only last for very short time. You don't need to lose a lot of water to bring down the temperature of the water to equilibrium with outer space.
I didn't say evaporate.  I said boil.  Those are two different things.

As a matter of fact, the evaporation of water takes so much energy, only a fraction of the water evaporate will bring most of water to freezing point. So in space the majority of the water will not evaporate.

I mentioned that you need a lot of water first, not just a small amount. The evaporation will happen only in the surface. Otherwise there will be no comet in space, in your logic all the water on comet should go quickly. As water temperature drops lower and lower(evaporated molecule is at higher energy, the molecule left behind will have lower and lower energy), the evaporation will slow down, so the ice in space will stay for long long time.

Water would boil immediately in space.  Not freeze.  You might have some tiny ice crystals remaining, but the vast majority of it would vaporize very very quickly because the boiling point of water decreases as the air pressure decreases.  It wouldn't have time to freeze.

If you are standing next to a road as a car passes, you notice that the pitch of the sound as it passes you goes down.  This is because the sound waves from a car moving toward you approach at a higher frequency than the sound actually coming from the car, and at a lower frequency as it passes and moves away from you.  This is the Doppler Effect.   Objects that are moving away from you will appear more red than they actually are, and they ALL appear more red, so they are all moving away.

Light travels at ~300,000 km/s.  A light year is the distance light travels in a year.  The time it take to travel one light year obviously depends on how fast you are going.  In your car going 70mph?  About 9.5 million years.  If you are going the speed of light?  1 year.

The Milky Way is 100,000 light years across.  Our sun is 30,000 light years from the center, and is only orbiting at a little over 200 km/s.  That is SLOW.  Even if you would expect the spirals to thin out and ultimately vanish (since the outer parts are orbiting slower), you would not see this change until several hundred million years had passed. Another way to think of it is :

The force of gravity increases the closer you are to the center of the black hole (things get weird when you approach the event horizon, so this only deals with the stars orbiting the black hole). Since the force increases, then the acceleration due to gravity also increases which means to maintain your orbit closer to the black hole, your angular/orbital velocity must increase to keep from falling into the black hole because of the increased acceleration.

There is a black hole at the center of the galaxy.  All the stars in the galaxy are orbiting this black hole.  Just like any other orbit, the closer you are to the mass you are orbiting, the higher the orbital velocity required to maintain the orbit.  Just like the satellites orbiting the Earth.  The ISS is is Low Earth Orbit about 350-400 km up, and it is orbiting at ~7.6 km/s while satellites in geostationary orbit 35,786 km high are only orbiting at 3.07 km/s.  All orbits follow this pattern

But the story doesn’t end there. Once the water has boiled, we now have some isolated water molecules in a gaseous state, but a very, very cold environment! These tiny water vapor droplets now immediately freeze (or, technically, desublimate), and become ice crystals.

The Cosmic Microwave Background, bathes the entire Universe in a temperature of only 2.7 Kelvin. That’s less than 3 degrees above absolute zero, or -455 degrees Fahrenheit! But there’s also — literally — no pressure in space. So, what happens? Does the water freeze or boil?
The answer is first one, and then the other! It turns out that having a pressure vacuum will cause the water to boil almost instantly. In other words, the effect of boiling is much, much faster than the effect of freezing.

When we say "powered by", we can refer to source of energy or the device used to do work. Cars are powered by fossil fuels, or cars are powered by internal combustion engines. If we take the first meaning, sun is powered by hydrogen fusion. Even if we take the second meaning, gravity is only part of the picture. You need gravity and critical mass to maintain continuous fusion. Earth also has gravity but the gravity does not "power" the earth.

Most galaxies are redshifted - meaning they are either travelling away from us, or the universe's expansion is making them further away, or both. Imagine our solar system is that piece of paper and the sun is in the center.  The planets are objects falling into the Sun (dent it makes).  The Sun's mass makes a dent in paper (space-time).  But since our Sun is also moving around the galaxy, the planets never run into the Sun but orbit it like his example.

No it doesn't.  Sound is a mechanical wave, meaning that it needs a physical medium to travel through.  Gravity is not a physical object that we can touch, but rather a force that we can feel. Gravity only affects particles, while sound is the phenomena caused by vibrating particles.  Sound is also not a physical object, therefore it isn't affected by gravity.  IF the vibrating particles cannot escape the pull of gravity, then the sound will not be heard.

What is gravity?

Gravity is a force pulling together all matter (which is anything you can physically touch). The more matter, the more gravity, so things that have a lot of matter such as planets and moons and stars pull more strongly.

Gravitational force in empty space is very weak because the small particles aren't large enough to exert any significant pull.

There just isn't enough mass in space to freeze any large amount of water. Yes, if a hydrogen atom floating around in space hit the water, the water would impart a great deal of energy to the single atom, but that can't take away enough energy from the water to freeze any conceivable amount.

Space being 3 Kelvin, it would be able to freeze the water if it actually had the density for that kind of energy transfer. With some parts of space as tight a vacuum as a single alpha particle for every cubic meter of space, how is the water going to freeze?

The water molecules in liquid water are at a mixture of temperatures, the measured temperature of the water is only the average temperature of all the molecules. In a vacuum, all of the molecules that are above the boiling point of water in at that pressure (or lack thereof) boil out of the blob of water until only the molecules that are below the boiling point (which is also below the 0C in a vacuum) are left. The remaining molecules are all below the freezing point so they form ice.

Shooting a stream of water in space wouldn't freeze it. The water would boil extremely quickly. Objects lose heat slowly in space, since they can only give off heat energy through radiation. Plus a liquids boiling point is related to atmospheric pressure. Increase pressure, the boiling point goes up, and decrease pressure, and decrease boiling point. So zero atmospheric pressure, essentially means zero temperature needed to boil water.
